posts.text_en:
A small poll ‚Äî drop your must-read books in the comments. Like, what you think absolutely has to be read üôÇ
I‚Äôve got a few principles by which I filter out literature or articles:
1/ any popular business books/articles can go to hell ‚Äî they‚Äôre written with the idea they have to land on a wide audience, which means they‚Äôll be exploiting ideas ‚Äúas close as possible to the broadest circle of people,‚Äù namely:
‚Ä¢ how damn hard it is to do anything and how you need to work a lot (the corporate mantra; number of hours guarantees literally nothing, since it‚Äôs just a multiplier of your talents and understanding)
‚Ä¢ recipes for happiness (there aren‚Äôt any; if there were, we‚Äôd have noticed for sure)
‚Ä¢ lessons from mistakes (it‚Äôs very hard to derive; nobody knows the whole story, usually it‚Äôs only a part)
2/ any books that are basically TV shows ‚Äî conditional Harry Potter and so on ‚Äî for me it‚Äôs easier to just watch the movie
3/ books about successful success

My small personal reading list:
1/ History: In the Shadow of the Sword (Arab history), Hobsbawm (just about everything), History of Western Philosophy, Commentaries on the Gallic War, When the King Loses France (Druon)
2/ Philosophy: Seneca (so life‚Äôs easier, so to speak; Stoics are useful), Schopenhauer, early Nietzsche, Heidegger (to understand the modern)
3/ Science: The Evolution of Physics (Einstein), Surely You‚Äôre Joking, Mr. Feynman (well this is more like entertainment), The Emperor‚Äôs New Mind (Penrose): here I only know physics, I can‚Äôt do the rest and I don‚Äôt know it
4/ Economics: Adam Smith, Piketty, Damodaran
5/ Just in the background: The Laws of Leadership (Roosevelt), World Order (Kissinger), Descartes‚Äô Discourse on Method, I also recommend reading the Quran (well, an adaptation or some simple translation)

Jobs, health, apps, pulse (news), –∏ —Ç–∞–∫ –¥–∞–ª–µ–µ. –°–ª–µ–≥–∫–∞ –Ω–∞–ø–æ–º–∏–Ω–∞–µ—Ç –ø–æ—Ä—Ç–∞–ª—ã –≤–µ–±–∞ 2.0 —Ç–∏–ø–∞ Yahoo, Rambler, –≥–ª–∞–≤–Ω—É—é –Ø–Ω–¥–µ–∫—Å–∞ –º–æ–º–µ–Ω—Ç–∞–º–∏. –ò–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–µ—Å–Ω–æ, –≤—Å–µ —Ç–∞–∫ –∂–µ –ø—Ä–∏–¥–µ—Ç –µ–¥–∏–Ω—ã–π –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–µ–π—Å –Ω–∞ —Å–º–µ–Ω—É –≤–µ—Ä—Ç–∏–∫–∞–ª—è–º –∏–ª–∏ –Ω–µ—Ç?
posts.text_en: I‚Äôm looking at what ChatGPT is shipping on its side. Jobs, health, apps, pulse (news), and so on. Kinda reminds me of Web 2.0 portals like Yahoo, Rambler, and at times Yandex‚Äôs homepage. Curious whether a single unified interface is still gonna come and replace the verticals, or not?

I‚Äôve got one of those red flags, as people like to say, when I look at some startup. Or a mid-sized company of like 50 people. But better a startup of 15‚Äì20.

It‚Äôs processes. Notions, spreadsheets, trackers, OKRs, stuffed calendars, millions of metrics and reports. And all of that when there‚Äôs no PMF, everything‚Äôs unprofitable, people keep leaving and coming back, pivots every six months.

Basically when processes and reports overshadow results ‚Äî that‚Äôs gg. Run.

Spotting it is dead simple: ask in the interview, ‚Äúso what do you use for tasks?‚Äù, if the answer takes longer than 2‚Äì3 minutes ‚Äî that‚Äôs a company where process matters more than result.

While the holidays were on I vibe-coded anything I could get my hands on.  
First, a couple of inputs:
- I last properly programmed something into production a long time ago, like 10 years ago probably ‚Äî last time I wrote something by hand from scratch and all the way to the end as a ready-to-use project, seriously
- I know the syntax of a lot of languages, I understand all the basic programming principles (all that OOP, functions, even remember how monads work)
- but I don‚Äôt write code, though I can read any algorithmic trick, but I can‚Äôt do architecture stuff (it eats too much time)

What I tried:
- a frontend for a reader a-la  
https://alphaxiv.org/
- make the exact same thing as a Mac app
- did various connections to our framework, like a plugin for Zed to use models that run through our uzu inference engine
- modifications of different repos to support local inference, for example here  
https://github.com/alexzhang13/rlm
- solving various tasks in math analysis and olympiad programming from Kvant magazine (well, whoever remembers will get it)

In the end:
- frontend is a disaster for me, I straight up don‚Äôt know web programming at all, so I just can‚Äôt get what I want, the interface keeps sliding around, I fought for hours just to align stuff to a grid or get PDF previews so nothing shifts
- the Mac app turns out ok if you remove the interface; with UI it‚Äôs the same as web, but stuff like menu bar plugins that search articles by my queries ‚Äî it does great
- any modifications and connnections, plugins somewhere, and simple API support, whether it‚Äôs our engine or something else, it does reliably almost from the first try, especially if you ask in advance to write an  
AGENTS.MD  
file in every repo so it‚Äôs easier to glue them together
- it solves problems head-on pretty well, but if I try to write a bot for some game or trading in a game, basic math is a mess. Mean is median, median is mean, and so on. Primitive mistakes, and fixing them only works by hand. If your chain has a bunch of computations, it just can‚Äôt carry it through to the end. It only works if you force it to write tests for every step. But imo for these tasks that‚Äôs overkill.

Bottom line. The progress is very noticeable. Codex, in my opinion, is smarter for one-shot stuff, but Claude code is for projects that are wrapped in tests and md instructions at every step. For now it feels like the stage of writing integrations, connections, basic things and review is close to automation. But architecture and math in code are hard. UI I‚Äôm not even gonna talk about ‚Äî either I‚Äôm doing something wrong, or it‚Äôs completely busted and it can‚Äôt improve anything beyond what came out in the one shot.

I use every day:
- Claude code with plugins, type the command /plugin and there‚Äôll be a sea of useful stuff
- cursor
- codex via the web client

I want to talk a bit about cofounders and choosing who to work with on a project.  
There‚Äôs this popular trait you‚Äôll see in a lot of people whose interviews, posts, stories, etc. you come across ‚Äî ‚Äúthe desire to be an ideological leader.‚Äù  
This type of personality has signs:
- they come up with ideas fast  
- they sell these ideas well  
- but for some reason the ideas rarely make it to the execution that was intended  
- it‚Äôs really hard for them to work with their hands and ‚Äúin the trenches‚Äù  

You can easily find founders like this on the internet. They usually give a lot of interviews, and pretty much all their advice is based on general principles (motivation, the future, and so on). You‚Äôll rarely see professional advice from them, analysis of their market segment, etc.  

The most common setup for founders like this is roughly:
- they look for a less experienced workhorse, preferably with a team (2‚Äì5 people)  
- the workhorse is less experienced in the venture industry and raising money, so it‚Äôll be very hard to find a common language with the person who ‚Äúprovides the company with funds‚Äù  
- that kind of founder will juggle ideas very fast, and raise money fast too  
- but they can‚Äôt make it past Series A, meaning it‚Äôs this forever-alive company, a builder of ideas that never gets to scaling or selling  
- their share is usually 80%, everyone else splits the remaining 20% (you get the idea)  
- teams like that are usually very uneven in hard skills, and in the market you‚Äôll feel how you‚Äôre falling behind  

What am I getting at. For many, this is the fastest way to get relevant experience, but it‚Äôs not a way to get a ‚Äúworking product,‚Äù an experiment the market needs, and so on. So my advice: work with people like that, but get out of the cycle in time and start your own thing. Look for a cofounder who‚Äôs your equal, but has a different skill set. Build your network while you‚Äôre working with people like that.
What‚Äôs up with startups in 2025 ‚Äî here, catch the full PDF from Carta

Dear friends, readers (both male and female), happy upcoming New Year to everyone! All the best! And may your goals come true!  
In the new year, as always, more interesting opinions, results, and victories await us!

Cool year-end infographic for the channel, I‚Äôd obviously add links and stuff you can copy and all that. But it came out funny. You can test it on your channel here  
https://tgwrapped.com

You know all those images with stats on who raises how much and at what stage. Like, on average it‚Äôs this much, and here are three founders, and here are the dilution percentages. Treat that info very carefully.  

If you‚Äôre building your own company or product, you need to have your own stance on all of this:
- how much money you need and for what
- for what period you need that money
- what you‚Äôre going to get for that cash
- equity, salaries, and the rest is your decision; sure, there will always be recommendations‚Äîread them, understand where they came from and why they are the way they are

Without experience, all these questions seem very hard. But in reality you just need to rough it out (nobody‚Äôs going to punish you for mistakes‚Äîyour project‚Äôs chances of dying just go up). Answer honestly how much you need, and then you always start from a number 2‚Äì3x higher (the more spending freedom, the better).  

Keep these factors in mind:
- venture assumes you‚Äôll keep raising later; dilution roughly drops by half with each new round
- venture is about growth, so the faster you show growth, the better (don‚Äôt confuse that with run rate or ‚Äúspent a million, got a million‚Äù as a result); you have to define what growth is for your product yourself

My advice is usually this. Talk to people, everyone you can reach. But don‚Äôt take their experience on pure faith. Talk to 5‚Äì10 people. Usually anyone has 10‚Äì15 minutes to answer your questions. Ideally, prep the most important questions for yourself in advance.

Imagine it.  
Where  
we ended up, wow wow (nah)  
You can check out the landing here  
trymirai.com

Carpathes, as usual, put out a solid, technically readable (meaning you don‚Äôt have to remember linear algebra) summary of this year in AI, or more precisely LLM.  
Recommend it.

Let me tell you a story. Back when I was a student, at uni we put together a team and made all sorts of ‚Äústartup crafts.‚Äù Like our own Foursquare, which in the US they went and ‚Äúinvented‚Äù a couple months later, and a bunch of totally pointless but fun stuff, like ‚Äúa desktop widget where you could set an emoticon for your mood for the day.‚Äù Sometimes those projects even brought in decent money, and I even wrote some articles on Habr.

So one day we went with one of those ideas (pretty sure it was the Foursquare thing with photos on a map) to a startup contest where one of the judges was Arkady Moreynis. And I remember his ‚Äúline of attack‚Äù really well:
- okay okay okay, why not Facebook events or photos
- what‚Äôs the business model? How do you make money?
- yeah, you guys are clear

And he said it all rough, with this vibe like ‚Äúhe‚Äôs seen all these student ideas in a coffin.‚Äù So yeah, that‚Äôs the very person who pretty much finished off the desire to do anything in me. And not because the questions were supposedly hard or I answered wrong. But because his attitude, his phrases, and other ‚Äúhints‚Äù completely killed any desire in all the guys around to do anything except ‚Äúbuy-sell.‚Äù

After that I spent a long time thinking what makes this guy so great, worked for a long time first in outsourcing, then at Yandex, then at Mail, and it still didn‚Äôt click. Yeah, he sold something back at the dawn of the internet and wrote a ton of articles. And then he went to the Valley, made a pretty successful product, and I realized ‚Äî nothing. Took away a lesson for myself: to hand out criticism in a certain industry you need to have experience in it, and preferably not from 20 years ago.

Got a bit sick here. But stumbled on this lovely piece of work. Like, to make new discoveries in science, LLMs need ideas, fresh new ideas. On its own it doesn‚Äôt pull. But as an assistant for brainstorming ‚Äî just the thing.

Pretty paper.

Busy though, OpenAI is running everywhere.  
https://openai.com/index/disney-sora-agreement/  
And all for this  
probably

Recommendation time, this time about venture and co, and all of venture right now is about AI, so it ends up being about that too.

When you‚Äôve raised rounds yourself, it‚Äôs always interesting to look at the market through the eyes of the people making decisions on the other side of the table: how they read demand, what they look at in the metrics, why one team looks convincing and another doesn‚Äôt.

I recommend Sasha Zhuravlev‚Äôs channel from Mento VC. The fund invests in B2B-AI in the Valley alongside Sequoia, a16z, Index, GV (not lead and co-lead, but deals where those funds are in).

Sasha shows what funds actually see: where real demand is hiding, which signals decide the outcome of a deal, why some AI teams make it through screening and others don‚Äôt, and what‚Äôs behind today‚Äôs valuations. He also shares the fund‚Äôs internal stuff: from deal sourcing to understanding why some teams grow faster than others.

For anyone who‚Äôs ever thought about their own investments or just wants to understand venture from the POV of people inside the deals ‚Äî subscribe. comment.
@exitsexist

Reminder of the golden rule of job hunting and who to work with. Your manager should be downright unpleasant, the kind who constantly challenges you, who talks to you but doesn‚Äôt soothe you‚Äîget references on them (that‚Äôs normal). Always, remember always, ask them questions point-blank at the interview. Any kind, from salary to their attitude to weekends and all that.

Interesting facts from my beloved a16z:
1/ more and more people are going off to build their own companies when hiring is hurting
2/ more and more late-stage companies are getting by with fewer people than they used to before

So, like, something to read and poke around in the history of one of the most important companies ‚Äî Google.  
It‚Äôs a compilation of letters from Larry, Sergey, and later Sundar, up to 2018. Every year they‚Äôd write up the key points for the company, the focus, the strategy, shaped the culture. The very beginning is insanely interesting, and how everything changes ‚Äî and fast. That‚Äôs where the 70-20-10 rule comes from about investing in the current, new, and risky business, the famous Don‚Äôt be evil etc. The evolution of ads and so on. I recommend reading it in ‚Äútogether with ChatGPT‚Äù mode. The document‚Äôs huge.

Lately people keep coming asking, or asking me to help find someone for their startup or wherever. And the description often looks like this:
A great and mighty founder with a super track record is looking for a founding engineer for a new awesome project.

I mean, I get it, sure, but there‚Äôs no link to the founder, no track record (like, all his projects are badass and he‚Äôs got a ton of exits, but no links), there isn‚Äôt even a proper description of the new project (if God willing there‚Äôs a link ‚Äî it‚Äôs basically just a name and lines like ‚Äúwe‚Äôll change the world‚Äù).

Either I don‚Äôt get something, or how did these people ever hire anyone before. How do you sell your idea without even saying who you are and what you are. Oh yeah, and the best part. The founder should be looking themselves, even if they‚Äôre super cool. Because we know those projects: ‚Äúit‚Äôs interesting for half a year, and then meh, got bored, no traction or whatever.‚Äù

Modern venture funds aka  
https://www.a67z.com  
P.S. every joke has a bit of joke in it

Rage bait section for your comments.  
Long story short I also think software engineering is dead. But unlike the loudmouth statements from leaders of big AI labs I‚Äôll try to explain what the whole point is here.

Most modern tech/software businesses are optimization. But not value add in the broad sense, for the end user. I‚Äôll try to explain.

Software is basically automation for the end user. For you and me it‚Äôs time savings. Any consumer product boils down to saving an irreplaceable resource ‚Äî time. Through money, speed, emotions, doesn‚Äôt really matter.

For those products to exist, a ton of different solution paths got built. You take the value delivery chain to the user and you do it. And in that chain there were always hard steps:
- different buttons have to work
- async so it sends requests to check if the username is taken
- payments so it‚Äôs easy to pay
- and so on

Then for all those steps, provider-optimizers appeared. They give you a ready-made chunk so you don‚Äôt write your own because it‚Äôs expensive and slow. That‚Äôs how the SaaS model showed up.

The second category is personalization. Ads and the internet are very personalized. You might not notice it but it is. For this to become real, a massive amount of work was done. Tons of algorithms and models make it so the next video after a swipe hits.

So where am I going with this. To the fact that most of these businesses are just not needed if all these automations and optimizations can be ‚Äúvibe-coded‚Äù by a model. In such a world you buy hardware and it writes all the software for you on the fly. It can be familiar or not. That‚Äôs all details.

So in that scenario you don‚Äôt need the following:
- analytics for decision-making ‚Äî why, if every part of solving the user‚Äôs problem is written optimally for the user himself
- A/B tests and other crap
- payments, storage, and the rest become services, ideally they‚Äôll be written from scratch (unless you‚Äôre the one holding the value ‚Äî like a bank)

You can fantasize further, but 80% of software business as we know it just isn‚Äôt needed.

Why all these support/debug/etc businesses if it‚Äôll be solved on the fly. We used to hire people who wrote deterministic solution scripts. Now you don‚Äôt have to. Because all solved tasks and optimizations will be written with AI.

That‚Äôs how I understand the ‚Äúsoftware engineering is dead‚Äù lines. In such a world there‚Äôs no place for apps and the software we‚Äôre used to. My forecast: 10‚Äì15 years.

You can like  
the English version  
over on my LinkedIn.

posts.text_en:
The other day an interesting
publication
dropped on lesswrong/greaterwrong about how supposedly Claude doesn‚Äôt just have a system prompt, but a whole identity baked straight into the weights, and there‚Äôs a document that this work on tuning was done off of (well after pretrain).
This thing is called a soul document. Smells kinda like pathos, sure. But the topic‚Äôs interesting. Let‚Äôs do a quick ‚Äúso what‚Äôs in there‚Äù.
- basically the document is ‚Äúcharacter training‚Äù, it sets full-on personal and moral settings for the model
- the model is explicitly fed the idea that it serves the business of the company that created it (doomers at this point should be outright happy ‚Äî what a plotline!)
- the document is, essentially, a compromise between altruism and commercial rationality: the model is supposed to both help people and ensure the stability of the company developing it
- unclear how well this approach actually works or if it‚Äôs just recommendations for tuning the system prompt? Does this kind of training scale, or is it in-context injection?
Most interesting part is that apparently the ladies and gents on Twitter
confirmed
the document is real, didn‚Äôt say what for or how.
I liked this paragraph from the doc:
Anthropic occupies a peculiar position in the AI landscape: a company that genuinely believes it might be building one of the most transformative and potentially dangerous technologies in human history, yet presses forward anyway.
No idea how real all of this is, but for some reason it‚Äôs exactly ‚Äúthese‚Äù kinds of topics that keep floating around Anthropic. Plus the company is omega closed.
Instead of:
 ‚Ä¢ blacklist
 ‚Ä¢ policy checks
 ‚Ä¢ simple ‚Äúavoid harmful content‚Äù.
Anthropic does:
 ‚Ä¢ character architecture
 ‚Ä¢ internalized values
 ‚Ä¢ narrative identity
What do you think? Getting ready for AGI? Or just pumping the hype?

Some kinda regular column ‚Äúread, but didn‚Äôt fully get it‚Äù, this time there‚Äôll be a lot of ‚Äúwatched‚Äù

1/ there‚Äôs this author I love in the physics world, Roger Penrose, he‚Äôs got a series of pretty interesting interviews on one channel (the dude doesn‚Äôt believe in the Big Bang theory and in quantum mechanics as anything final), recommend it, plus he‚Äôs also in Sutskever‚Äôs camp (well, philosophically): you can‚Äôt just do what works today (for Ilya that‚Äôs about scaling the little nets)

2/ A DeepMind documentary, the previous ones were top, so you gotta watch this one too ‚Äî the comment basically captures what‚Äôs going on: Nah I don't really want a million dollars thanks, I've got better things to do with my time ‚Äî a 17-year-old kid

3/ a bunch of people have put out reviews of the Deepseek paper about what approach nets use to solve all those olympiad problems (I guess everyone‚Äôs more or less saying the same thing), so if you‚Äôre interested I recommend checking it out (the paper is readable with mid-level prep). In short: you need value-based intermediate proof-ish stuff so you can verify what‚Äôs happening along the way, instead of just going to the end and checking whether the answer is correct or not

4/ In the Shadow of the Sword about the rise of Islam, just a damn awesome work that gets cited a lot, recommend it to history enjoyers

5/ A cool hole in vibe-coding agents (don‚Äôt know if it hits all IDEs and so on), but it‚Äôs straight-up a classic, so watch your access keys and API keys too

6/ And a movie for your weekend: ‚ÄúDead Poets Society‚Äù

7/ One of my favorite n+1 articles about levels of complexity in science + an old meme from Elon

Let‚Äôs go watch! Review later  
https://youtu.be/aR20FWCCjAs?si=UfsdvKYRbRi7qCWW

 –ø—Ä–æ —Ä—ã–Ω–æ—á–µ–∫ tech –æ—Ç Ben Evans, –∫–æ–Ω–µ—á–Ω–æ –∂–µ –ø—Ä–æ AI. –ö—Ä–∞–π–Ω–µ —Ä–µ–∫–æ–º–µ–Ω–¥—É—é –æ–∑–Ω–∞–∫–æ–º–∏—Ç—å—Å—è —Ö–æ—Ç—è –±—ã —Ä–∞–¥–∏ –∫—Ä–∞—Å–∏–≤—ã—Ö —Ü–∏—Ç–∞—Ç:

posts.text_en:
Once every six months there‚Äôs this
wonderful report
on the tech market by Ben Evans, obviously about AI. I highly recommend checking it out at least for the pretty quotes:
‚ÄúAI is whatever machines can‚Äôt do yet‚Äù
Larry Tesler, 1970
